TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit AvailabilityAttribute extends System.Attribute

Docs.summary: Describes the availability of a member or type in iOS or MacOS.

remarks.para: It is the managed equivalent of Clang's availability __attribute__, which is the underlying mechanism that Apple uses to annotate introduction, deprecation, obsoleteness, and unavailability of APIs on a per-platform basis (currently Mac OS X and iOS).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

public AvailabilityAttribute (MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform introduced, MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform deprecated = MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform.None, MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform obsoleted = MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform.None, MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform unavailable = MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform.None);

.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform introduced, valuetype MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform deprecated, valuetype MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform obsoleted, valuetype MonoTouch.ObjCRuntime.Platform unavailable) cil managed

Docs.param: The first version in which an API was introduced for a given platform.

The first version in which the API was deprecated for a given platform; this means users should begin avoiding the API and migrating to a more suitable one, but it still technically works on the platform, but there is no guarantee for how long it will continue to work.

The first version in which the API was obsoleted (removed) from a given platform; this means the API no longer exists and cannot be used at all - a crash at runtime will occur if used on Xamarin. Native code referencing obsolete API will fail to compile (the attribute is enforced by Clang).

The API has never existed in a given platform (e.g. available in iOS but not in Mac); this property is not versioned (can only be Platform.{None,Mac,iOS}) and applies to the entire lifetime (up to present) of a platform. "Unavailable" may be replaced in future versions by an "Introduced."
Docs.summary: Defines the availability range of a particular API.

remarks.para: The entire availability of an API can be expressed either with a single Availability attribute or with multiple. It's entirely style. To demonstrate this, Since, Lion, and MountainLion are now actually subclasses of Availability. This is because we do not want to break API, but also often the more terse attributes are simply nicer to use.
In addition to the AvailabilityAttribute types, there's also which contains a number of useful utilities for working with the Platform enumeration.

example.code:
// // The following examples are all equivalent // [Since (4,0), Lion, Availability (Deprecated = Platform.iOS_6_0 | Platform.Mac_10_8)] ...
[Availability (Introduced = Platform.iOS_4_0)] ...
[Availability (Introduced = Platform.Mac_10_7)] ...
[Availability (Deprecated = Platform.iOS_6_0 | Platform.Mac_10_8)] ...
[Availability ( Introduced = Platform.iOS_4_0 | Platform.Mac_10_7, Deprecated = Platform.iOS_6_0 | Platform.Mac_10_8 )] ...

Docs.summary: the first version in which the API was deprecated for a given platform; this means users should begin avoiding the API and migrating to a more suitable one, but it still technically works on the platform, but there is no guarantee for how long it will continue to work.

Docs.remarks: The API has never existed in a given platform (e.g. available in iOS but not in Mac); this property is not versioned (can only be Platform.{None,Mac,iOS}) and applies to the entire lifetime (up to present) of a platform. "Unavailable" may be replaced in future versions by an "Introduced."
